Dimensions.title: Assessing the Value of Grazed Corn Residue for Crop and Cattle Producers

Semantic Scholar.abstract: Integrated crop–livestock systems have included grazing perennial grasses during the spring and summer and corn (Zea mays L.) residues during the winter. Our objectives were to identify opportunities for expanded corn residue use through grazing and provide an economic assessment for value-added grazing. We estimated the economic value to the crop sector through grazing leased corn residue at over $95 million for Nebraska, South Dakota, Kansas, and North Dakota under current management. Additionally, gross economic value to the livestock sector in these states was estimated at greater than $191 million. Advantages for increased grazing use of corn residue include managing residue quantity in high-yielding environments, providing a source of supplemental revenue, and expanding integrated crop–livestock systems using a simple, but cost-efficient practice. D. Redfearn, Dep. of Agronomy and Horticulture, Univ. Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68583; J. Parsons, Dep. of Agricultural Economics, Univ. Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68583; M. Drewnoski and J. MacDonald, Dep. of Animal Science Univ. Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68583; M. Schmer, USDA-ARS, Agroecosystem Management Research Unit, Lincoln, NE 68583; R. Mitchell, USDA-ARS, Wheat, Sorghum, and Forage Research Unit, Lincoln, NE 68583; J. Farney, Southeast Agricultural Research and Extension Center, Kansas State Univ., Parsons, KS 67357; A. Smart, Dep. of Natural Resources Management, South Dakota State Univ., Brookings, SD 57007. Core Ideas • Grazed corn residue is a cost-efficient forage

Dimensions.title: Beginning Farmers and Ranchers at a Glance

Semantic Scholar.abstract: Beginning farmers and ranchers have some unique characteristics, including more education and more off-farm jobs, compared with established farmers and ranchers.
